pullRequest.body:
* `AlgebraicIndependent.extendScalars`: if A/S/R is a tower of algebras with S/R algebraic, then a family of elements in A that are algebraically independent over R remains algebraically independent over S, provided that S has no zero divisors.

* `AlgebraicIndependent.algebraicClosure`: an algebraically independent family remains algebraically independent over the algebraic closure.

To prove these, we slightly change the statement of `algebraicIndependent_of_finite(_type)'` to keep a hypothesis inherited from `Set.Finite.induction_on'` to make induction work.

---

- [x] depends on: #19660

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ adjoin_of_disjoint`
`+ algebraicClosure`
`+ algebraicIndependent_of_finite_type`
`+ algebraicIndependent_singleton_iff`
`+ extendScalars`

`+ extendScalars_of_isSimpleRing`

</details>

```

```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

I realize this is very close to well-definedness of transcendence degree, so if @acmepjz is not already working on it I'll try soon.

> I realize this is very close to well-definedness of transcendence degree, so if @acmepjz is not already working on it I'll try soon.

Thank you very much! I have no plan yet. Feel free to work on it.

:v: alreadydone can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thanks!
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12434917724/job/34719617318)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12434917724/job/34719616990)
bors d+
Thank you very much! Looks good.
bors d+

This and the above `adjoin_of_disjoint` should also have a `IntermediateField.adjoin` version. Would you like to add them?

Also, `transcendental_adjoin` should also have an `iff` version, which could be a `simp` lemma.

Maybe `adjoin_of_disjoint` also have an `iff` version?

I'm thinking of applications to `MvPolynomial` to obtain similar results in https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Algebraic/MvPolynomial.html but for `AlgebraicIndependent`.

> Also, `transcendental_adjoin` should also have an `iff` version, which could be a `simp` lemma. Maybe `adjoin_of_disjoint` also have an `iff` version?

I added these, but `simp` lemmas with an `AlgebraicIndependent` hypothesis seem weird, so I didn't mark them `@[simp]`.

> This and the above `adjoin_of_disjoint` should also have a `IntermediateField.adjoin` version. Would you like to add them?

They don't fit in this file due to required import, so not in this PR.

> > Also, `transcendental_adjoin` should also have an `iff` version, which could be a `simp` lemma. Maybe `adjoin_of_disjoint` also have an `iff` version?
> 
> I added these, but `simp` lemmas with an `AlgebraicIndependent` hypothesis seem weird, so I didn't mark them `@[simp]`.

Oh I forgot it. That's OK.
 
> > This and the above `adjoin_of_disjoint` should also have a `IntermediateField.adjoin` version. Would you like to add them?
> 
> They don't fit in this file due to required import, so not in this PR.

I see. Maybe later I'll add them to another file if they are needed.

Maybe you can use `algebraicIndependent_of_finite'`, `aevalEquiv` and [MvPolynomial.transcendental_supported_X](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Algebraic/MvPolynomial.html#MvPolynomial.transcendental_supported_X) to prove this result. I'm not sure if the proof will be shorter or longer, but you need to import a new file.
Changing the base ring (from `adjoin` to `supported`) is tricky, but it's apparently an art you mastered (many `comp_eq` lemmas I recall ...) I'd rather not go that route ...

>  I'd rather not go that route

That's OK.
Isn't it more general to assume `E/F` is algebraic, and then extend to `E`?
I'm not sure what you mean? If E/F is algebraic then x can't be alg. indep. over F unless Î¹ is empty, which is very restrictive / vacuous rather than general.

Whoops, you are right. What I should have said is that we can have a tower of fields. And so we can replace `algebraicClosure F E` by any `L` such that `F/L/E` is a tower of fields, and `L/E` is algebraic.
Does that make more sense?

> Whoops, you are right. What I should have said is that we can have a tower of fields. And so we can replace `algebraicClosure F E` by any `L` such that `F/L/E` is a tower of fields, and `L/E` is algebraic. Does that make more sense?

I think it's just `AlgebraicIndependent.extendScalars` which is also added in this PR.

But that needs an injectivity assumption.
Wouldn't the lemma that I describe be a strict generalization of this current one?

> But that needs an injectivity assumption. Wouldn't the lemma that I describe be a strict generalization of this current one?

OK I think a `AlgebraicIndependent.extendScalars_field` may be added, which assumes in A/S/R that `S` is a field.
It's enough to assume IsSimpleRing, since RingHom.injective has been generalized to simple rings. I've added that version.
So now this lemma is the special case `S := algebraicClosure F E`, right?

> It's enough to assume IsSimpleRing, since RingHom.injective has been generalized to simple rings. I've added that version.

But a commutative simple ring is automatically a field, no?
Indeed; but probably not worth adding a variable and associated typeclasses for the Field ...

> So now this lemma is the special case `S := algebraicClosure F E`, right?

Yes it works. [845521e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19708/commits/845521ed4a0cc575ef3f2c79aab317c92b9e6dd1)
Here, I think `integralClosure` can be replaced by any `Subalgebra R A` that `IsAlgebraic`.

Added two `subalgebra` versions in [ca2c60c](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19708/commits/ca2c60c135e4aa027e24709f8679714bcd037b29); the IsIntegral version is needed for the degenerate case R=0 where nothing is algebraic over R.
Thanks for including the generalizations. Do you think these special cases are still worth keeping? I don't have a strong opinion, but I feel like they aren't really needed anymore.

The original motivation is to derive [this statement](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/6718#discussion_r1843759066) that explicitly mentions `integralClosure`. I think it's convenient to write `hx.algebraicClosure` etc. to directly get the result without the need to write `algebraicClosure F E`.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(RingTheory): `AlgebraicIndependent` persists to `algebraicClosure`
